Content: Section B: Section B

Subject: Politics

Subject: Politics
Content:
Outline the perspective on Australia's pursuit of regional relationships in the Indo-Pacific region
presented in Source 2. Refer to information from Source 2.

Subject: Politics
Content:
Identify two types of foreign policy instruments used by Australia in the Indo-Pacific
region that are shown in Source 1.

Subject: Politics
Content:
Explain how Australia has used one of the types of foreign policy instruments
identified in part a to pursue either security or economic prosperity.

Subject: Politics
Content:
Discuss the effectiveness of Australia's cooperation with two states in the Indo-Pacific region. At least
one of your selected states must be a member of the Pacific Islands Forum. Refer to information from
Source 1 and/or Source 2 as well as your own knowledge.

Content: Section C: Section C

Subject: Politics

Subject: Politics
Content: Answer all questions in the spaces provided.

Subject: Politics

Subject: Politics
Content:
Analyse how states have challenged one global issue and one contemporary crisis that you have
studied this year. Use evidence to support your response.

Subject: Politics
Content:
With reference to one Indo-Pacific state that you have studied this year and Australia, evaluate the
effectiveness of their pursuit of regional relationships. Use evidence to support your response.
Extra space for responses
Clearly number all responses in this space.
If you use any additional Question and Answer Books to complete your responses, write your student
number on the front cover. At the end of the examination, place the additional Question and Answer
Books inside the front cover of the first Question and Answer Book.
Assessment criteria for Section
The two extended-response questions in Section C will be assessed against the following criteria:
•	 balanced exploration of the two areas of study within the specified unit
•	 development of a coherent and relevant argument that addresses the question
•	 demonstration of accurate and appropriate key knowledge
•	 application of relevant political thinking concepts such as cause and consequence, political interests
and perspectives, political stability and change, and political significance
•	 use of contemporary examples and case studies (within the last 10 years) as evidence to support
explanations, points of view and/or arguments
Victorian Curriculum and Assessment Authority 2025
